bibl.title: Letter from A.M. Stimson to L.D. Fricks, January 6, 1923

div1.p: Stimson asks Fricks to assign a man to survey a proposed anti-malaria project in order to devise a cost estimate for Congress.

div1.head: Letter from A.M. Stimson to L.D. Fricks, January 6, 1923
div1.p:
COPY
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
Washington
January 6, 1923. Surgeon L.D. Fricks,
U.S. Public Health Service,
Room 17 Court House Building,
Memphis, Tennessee.
Dear Dr. Fricks:

Colonel J.F. Siler of the Army Medical Corps rang meuup
yesterday saying that data were desired by the Senate committee
showing an estimate of the cost of antimalaria operations at the
Muscle Shoals project. For immediate information I referred him
to Dr. Carter, who furnished certain data of requirements by the
Federal Power Commission and the Public Health Service which could
be used as a basis for calculating the cost. This material is in
the hands of General L.H. Beach, Chief of Engineers, who is apparently
responsible for making this estimate.

I told Colonel Siler over the 'phone that if it was de-
sired we would endeavor to send an engineer to Muscle Shoals to make
a rapid survey on which estimates could be based, and this morning
he informed me that General Beach would prefer this means of arriv-
ing at an estimate. I beleive, therefore, that it would be good policy
for you to detail a man to make this survey which would include not
only the cost incidental to construction, but some estimate of the
annual upkeep.

I understand that General Beach is sending you a letter
which may be used at Muscle Shoals to facilitate the investigation.

From the Service's standpoint, my reason for complying
with the request for a survey is in order that opportunities for the
investigation of impounded water problems may be more readily secured
to the Service. The Army engineers apparently have no desire to deal
with the malaria aspect of the project beyond conforming with such
rules as it may be necessary to comply with.

Yours very truly,
(A.M. Stimson)
Assistant Surgeon General.
AMS:AEB.
WAD.

COPY.
WAR DEPARTMENT
Office of Chief of Engineers
Washington.
January 6, 1923. Refer to file No. 120483
Subject: Sanitary conditions surrounding pool abive Dam No. 2.
To: The District Engineer,
U.S. Engineer Office,
FLORENCE, ALABAMA.

1. The Public Health Service is engaged in an effort to
eradicate malaria in those parts of the country most subject to its
ravages. It has done considerable work in Alabama and adjacent States
The work of eradicating the mosquito in the pool at Dam No. 12 Coosa
River, was under its direction.

2. It is quite desirable that steps be inaugurated at an
early date to prevent the breeding of mosquitoes in the pool above
Dam No. 2 which you are constructing. This office has been conferr-
ing with the Public Health Service and informed that organization
that we did not have funds available for the purpose of mosquito
control. That the Service will endeavor to secure an appropriation
from Congress for the purpose, and with the object of making an es-
timate of the sum that will be needed, Surgeon L.D. Fricks of the U.S.
Public Health Service, whose office is in the Court House at Memphis,
Tenn., will send one or two doctors to Florence to look over the field
and ascertain what the exact conditions are so that the required am-
ount can be somewhat definitely determined.

3. You will give whoever will be sent by the Surgeon Fricks,
all possible information and assist him in every way to obtain as
complete data as possible so that the amount which may be needed can
be as accurately determined as it is possible to do so at this time.
4. A cpoy of this letter is being furnished Surgeon Fricks.

Lansing H. Beach
Chief of Engineers.
Copy -- WAD.
